comments.text:
Hasn't that already been done before? I think I remember seeing two 
versions, both also involving Celestia. Maybe you could think up a whole 
new idea to use with her, something that has never been done before. As for 
the content, it would depend for what kind of mood you want your first 
video to have.
comments.author: elderwolves

comments.text:
I was intending for it to be in 4-5 parts. Maybe your right. I think we'll 
hold off on this and start with something smaller. I never expected it to 
be one large video because that would take too long and I don't have the 
damn patience for that. I'll need to message my animator to hold off on 
that. In the mean time and make a teaser instead. Any recommendations for 
what I should start out with? I was thinking gamer Luna.
comments.author: NukeDaNoobs

comments.text:
+NukeDaNoobs Okay then. I'm flattered you want my opinion of this; fair 
warning: you may not feel that way for long. I can be rather blunt.

For starters, this feels like it's more focused on the outsider than it is 
the world it's based on. Depending on what you're going for, this could be 
very good or very bad. 
Another; didn't you say you wanted each episode to stand alone? The plot 
sounds too heavy and complicated to only be one episode (unless you do it 
in 'Parts', example: The Lunar Revolution: Part 1, The Lunar Revolution: 
Part 2; OR The Lunar Revolution: The Mark, The Lunar Revolution: The Sign. 
So you may want to consider that. But what you've told me sounds more like 
the premise for a movie. 
It's completely up to you and your team what you want to do, but this 
sounds a little heavy on the stomach for your first video. Kind of like 
starting cooking class and expecting to learn how to Souffle a la Escargot 
the first day. This would be a great Big Project, but I think it may be a 
little better if you tried something smaller and simpler to start with, 
just to get the kinks worked out.
Not too harsh, was it?
comments.author: elderwolves

comments.text:
I feel like the tension is rising. IDK why but my animator doesn't like 
talking to me on weekends ( probably because of school). I want your input 
on the idea off the first episodes. You're the first person that isn't 
working with me to know what it is.

Once again the changelings plan attack Canterlot, but they have a secret 
weaponry that will destroy all of Equestria. Seeing no other choice than to 
seek outside help , Twilight Sparkle, Princess Luna, Princess Celestia, and 
Princess Cadence summon a being in hopes of preventing total annihilation. 
They summon a teenage boy from the human world and all of pony kind's fate 
rests on his shoulders. Will Equestria become a waste land? Or will the 
human save them all?
comments.author: NukeDaNoobs

comments.text:
+NukeDaNoobs Likely it will. But I find that most artists I interact with 
are rarely satisfied with their own work. Myself included. Which is why the 
opinions of others is so important: they see what we may not be able to 
simply because we are too close to the project. Only time will tell. But 
I'm sure you'll do well.
comments.author: elderwolves

comments.text:
Undoubtedly it will lack good elements but you're right. Hopefully it goes 
better than I expect.
comments.author: NukeDaNoobs

comments.text:
That's good. Just be sure to take criticism with just as much grace as you 
do the advice. I've recently had the misfortune to come across a game 
developer who reacted rather poorly and childishly to a negative but honest 
review. It left me with a rather poor opinion of him, it did to many of us. 
So to you, I give this advice:
A critique is as valuable as any rave review, if not more. It can help you 
see flaws that you were to close to see before, and can give you an idea of 
how your audiences react (even if you don't like it). Look for merit in all 
that they say, and learn from what you find. And if you find that you 
heavily disagree with what was said, then be civil. A polite statement of 
your disagreement, especially in the more histaric situations, will earn 
you far more respect than a vehement "Fuck you!"
comments.author: elderwolves

comments.text:
+NukeDaNoobs You're probably right about the second episode. But what I was 
going to say was about the Crypt Keeper, a puppet made to look like a 
corpse. It took six people to animate him, but you could see a massive 
difference between the first episode and the last one. He used to have very 
limited motion that always seemed to be off and a little slow. By the last 
episode, he moved fluidly and a lot faster. Such will probably happen with 
your videos. Once you get used to it, you have the potential to really take 
off.

you'll probably find is that the Toy/Marketing department seems to be 
operating on a different planet from the actual show. The show surprisingly 
isn't brain melting like the older ones- and the main characters ARE 
ACTUALLY 20-ish (according to the creator and one of the writers). To know 
if you like it you NEED to watch past the first 2 background episodes to 
see what the show is really like. It's not 5 year-olds and their tea 
parties.

comments.text:
Yes and no. This is a 100% fan created video based off the show My Little 
Pony: Friendship Is Magic.
If it sparked your interest, I suggest you watch the show from the 
beginning. Just be forewarned that the first two-parter is not nessessarily 
indicative of what's to come - though you'll want to watch it for the 
established characters and settings. It's with episodes 3 and 4 that the 
series shows its true heading. So if you'd be turned off by a "Magical 
girls in Equestria" type of show, know that it goes another direction.
If you're not enchanted by episode 4, it'll probably never "click" for you.

furry fandom look lazy, I am ashamed to say.  Though I must add to the 
defense of the furry fandom that we have all costume making talent.

language when it is used to sing?  That's only my guess, because I find 
nothing about this song irritating at all.

of a bad connection or bad speakers.  Try a good pair of headphones to see 
if that helps.

top_comment.author: epic rainbow (dash)

comments.text:
Watch Neon Genesis Evangelion.
But seriously, there are a few reasons:
- It would be the easy way. Team Evil is in most cases much more powerful 
than the good guys. Them winning would make the story boring.
- Suspense. You want to root for the underdogs, and for them to overcome 
adversary in the end.
- Catharsis. When you become invested into the (good) characters, you feel 
their joy and share in their success. You don't really want to see them 
defeated.
- The story never told. Many stories start with an evil emperor/overlord, 
ruling over all the land. They already had their Happy Ending.
comments.author: Smilley MLK

comments.text: They do win. Have you seen the paycheck they get?
comments.author: E Robinson

top_comment.text:
She came upon nightfall, as myths of her say,
Her song, one of beauty, making little hearts sway;
For she, of the shadows, invited them to prance,
In her garden of moonbeams, beneath her, entranced.

She wished for their joy, though this joy was not blessed,
The elder sister, visionary, would not be impressed;
While the outlook was simple, to bring serenity to all,
Her big sister knew that balance was certain to fall.

So one night, as she slept, her little sister went out,
To call upon the fillies and colts without doubt;
She'd play upon their dreams with a melody of spite,
To lure them them all away to a kingdom of the night.

Her intentions, never wicked, would lure them all away,
So that with her they'd want to play and there forever stay;
For Luna's heart was filled with grief, a sorrow most forlorn,
She'd have their smiles, but to her sister, love would now be torn.

Reluctantly she found them each wherever they had slept,
In alleys under paper blankets, in beds where they had wept;
She called them all, her voice so clear, a siren's song she sang,
To lead them under stardust sky, where laughs, still silent, rang.

As midnight came, Celestia slept, thinking nothing could go wrong,
For little did she know that she would sleep for far too long;
The last thing that she could hear, was the fading of a song,
And when she woke, it was too late...all her children were gone...﻿

comments.text:
+Umbreon Gem
I do write poetry off and on, but I wouldn't call myself a poet. Much of 
poetry is about understanding, but that doesn't mean that there's just one 
right interpretation. It's all about perspective: what mood are you in when 
you read it, how do you feel the poem applies to the topic, is it true of 
everyone or just inone instance...stuff like that. Hey, I mean, you don't 
have to be Einstein to enjoy poetry. At least that's what I think.

top_comment.text:
*lights candle*
*writes this in journal:*
*"I still remember it like it was yesterday. Though it was countless moons 
ago. After 'he' was defeated. Not much of our once beautiful home was left. 
And the two brave ones that stood up for us all. Ruled Equestria from then 
on. One day, the younger one, saddened by our daily struggles, proposed to 
form a new colony where all of us would grow strong, and happy. But the 
elder one, forbade it..for she felt that it would divide and shatter the 
weakened kingdom..forever. Nopony knows that we are still here, smiling 
beneath the moonlight while remembering our dear mother. For we will 
forever be, her Children of the Night.*
*blows out candle*

Come little children
I'll take thee away
Into a land of enchantment
Come little children
The time's come to play
Here in my garden of shadows
Follow sweet children
I'll show thee the way
Through all the pain and the sorrows
Weep not poor children
For life is this way
Murdering beauty and passions
Hush now dear children
It must be this way
Too weary of life and deceptions
Rest now my children
For soon we'll away
Into the calm and the quiet
(sad noises)
Come little children
I'll take thee away
Into a land of enchantment
Come little children
The time's come to play
Here in my garden of shadows
(sad noises)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

top_comment.text:
...See, it's times like this that I regret learning Shakespearean English.

The lyrics are just a teensy bit off. You use 'thee' to refer to multiple 
people -- it should be 'you'. Yes, 'thee' sounds more old-timey, but it's 
specifically for addressing one person. "Come little children, I'll take 
thee away" addresses multiple.

Other than that, absolutely fantastic work.﻿
top_comment.author: TheNewbiedoodle

comments.text:
Really? Poe wrote this? Then it's still incorrect. It's just poetic 
license. 'Thee' is explicitly used for singular, and (here) Luna addresses 
all of the children, which clearly is not a single object. She doesn't 
address them as a single group, which would be 'thee'. She addresses them 
as multiple individuals, which is 'you'.

Could I get a link, though? I'd like to read Poe's original version.
comments.author: TheNewbiedoodle

comments.text:
It's about contextual use, it's perfectly fine in this instance, and as 
Edgar Alan Poe is generally credited with writing this I'm going to go 
ahead and assume his English was a touch better than yours is now!
comments.author: SuperWidgetMaster

comments.text:
After Discord was defeated, Equestria was left in ruins. Luna, upon seeing 
countless ponies trying to piece their shattered lives together again, 
proposed to Celestia to form a new colony elsewhere. But Celestia refused, 
feeling it would divide and shatter the weakened kingdom. Luna decided to 
ask for forgiveness rather than permission, and gathered her "children", 
foals who did not quite fit in. They formed a new colony, near what would 
become Ponyville. But Luna's heart was overcome by greed and jealousy, and 
Celestia was forced to banish her own sister. A statue of Nightmare Moon 
stands in the old colony, which is now known as the Everfree Forest.
comments.author: Ryan Twombly

You are missing the point. By seperating these children from the rest, Luna 
is dividing them from the rest of the 'poor ponies' of the land, ultimately 
separating them from the rest of equestria. What Celestia wants is a united 
kingdom where every pony has equal opportunities. Celestia worries about 
what Luna's action might cause. Why make a separate colony? It might only 
cause potential war in the future, as silly as that may sound.

Just because it seems pretty, beautiful, calm etc at first doesn't mean 
that it was ultimately the right thing to do.

comments.text:
+Emperor of Cartoons I probably shouldn't get involved but against my 
better judgement I will.

As I see it you should credit what you actually use, no matter if they were 
the original or not. That said if it's a cover it would be nice if it were 
mentioned (as it is), though that's as far as I anyone should have to go 
(Ideally that would mean that you could trace the original by following the 
credits of each cover).
For example if I used "Hound Dog" as sung by Elvis Presley I would credit 
him, not Big Mama Thornton despite her being the original artist (or Jerry 
Leiber and Mike Stoller that wrote it apparently). I probably wouldn't even 
say that Elvis version was a cover, though that's mostly because of how 
much more famous Elvis was and is.



My point is that the specific version matters more than whoever made it 
first, simply because it's easier to find out witch was the original than 
finding the version used.

top_comment.text:
I shall repeat myself once again: why does Luna use "thee" where "you" 
would be appropriate even for her time period? In Early Modern English, 
"thou" and its derivatives were used solely in informal speech and only 
when talking about a single person, whereas Luna addresses an entire group 
of children.﻿
top_comment.author: Imperios

comments.text: amen
comments.author: Breevee

comments.text:
The same reason why computer interfaces in movies animate all fancy when 
such interfaces would never do so in the real world. It communicates an 
idea much more explicitly to the common man who isn't well versed in the 
way such things actually work.

Ordinary people equate "thee" and "thou" with archaic speech, so the 
writers used them, regardless of historical accuracy. The bottom line is 
that Luna's speech is supposed to feel old, and it comes across just fine.

As a graphic designer, I do get a little irritated when computers have 
ridiculous interfaces or nanoscopic (or nonexistent) pixels, but that's 
just part of the medium: you have to do what the average person will 
understand.
comments.author: Omni Jacala

comments.text:
This song is pre-written. It was just used in this video. She says thee 
because It is part of the original song "Come Little Children" which is a 
lullaby. The maker of the video used this song by the artist permission. 
Hope this answered your question.
comments.author: Breevee

comments.text:
+Imperios I'll admit I'm not exactly educated in the field of archaic 
English, so I'll take your word for it. In that case, I don't know why she 
uses words like thee or thou where they are not supposed to be used. I 
suppose that's a question to take to the makers.
comments.author: AdelioNightstorm

comments.text:
That is the point I am trying to make. In Early Modern English (the 
language of KJV Bible and Shakespeare), which Luna's speech patters are 
modelled on, neither "thou" nor any of its derivatives were used to refer 
to a *group* of people (nor in any other form of English save perhaps for 
the dialect of the Amish, which Luna certainly does not use). It's like 
using "he" when talking about several people in modern English.

top_comment.text:
I'm well aware that the song in this video is basically a parody of a song 
used in the movie *Hocus Pocus*, but here's what I really want to type 
about: I was watching the Disney Movie *Return to Neverland* on the TV, 
when they went to a commercial break, then I decided to pass the time by 
watching |^| THIS |^| video on my computer, then I came to realize that the 
story used in this video is actually similar to the story of Peter Pan, 
Luna wanted to form a separate new colony where everyone could live strong 
& happily under the guidance of the Moon, but Celestia wanted the already 
weakened kingdom to remain united as one, so Luna decided to put her & the 
royal guards to sleep, while she sneaked out over the town, sought out 
children who were orphaned, abandoned, or just plain miserable, & used her 
powerful magic to levitate them all to a new place where they grew & smiled 
under the power of the Moon, thinking of Luna as their adopted mother, 
which is not too different from how Peter Pan sought out children & brought 
them to Neverland where they would never grow up & could remain as children 
forever, just a thought I came up with.﻿

appropriate.


And finally, I love both Celestia and Luna! I think both are amazing! Luna 
may be the relatable one. And Celestia may be the strong leader of the two. 
They need each other and every pony needs them. Also, I think poor Celestia 
doesn't get enough credit. Her job has been endless stress. Especially when 
she was forced to banish her own dear sister. She is rules over all of 
Equestria and must protect her subjects. She, also, is not perfect. She has 
made mistakes like dating a stallion even if it was dangerous for their

perfect in a way. I respect Celestia's character. I love both princesses 
equally.

top_comment.text:
I'm not a full-on Brony, more of a dabbler in all this stuff.  However, I 
*will* say that if you love content like this, you had better download and 
save your own copy.

Hasbro cares absolutely *nothing* about how much time, skill and passion 
are put into fan projects.  They demonstrated that very clearly with the 
Fighting is Magic game.  If their lawyers smell blood, they attack without 
mercy.

Granted, something like this is more likely to slip under the radar than a 
fighting game, but no one should *ever* assume their project is immune.  It 
doesn't matter how good the artist's intentions are, or how monetarily free 
the content is.﻿
top_comment.author: scarabmango

comments.text:
+binkyboy448
There's a line between protecting a copyright and overzealously squashing 
free content that happens to use your characters.  I feel that Hasbro has 
developed a nasty habit of the latter. 

And yes, I'm familiar with all the "Oh, but if they let X get away with it, 
then Y and Z will try to get away with it, and blah blah blah" arguments, 
so there's no need to get into them.

Rather than deal with legitimate copyright threats if and when they arise, 
akin to a surgical strike strategy, Hasbro seems to be veering toward more 
of a "tactical nuke" approach, and I feel that's overkill.
comments.author: scarabmango

comments.text:
You seem to be confusing "acting within copyright laws" for "bullying". I 
know that Hasbro's legal team is a third party that acts entirely on their 
own, but regardless of whether or not they're being heartless dicks, it's 
still their property and they have every right to protect it. I'll have you 
know that one team of animators has closely deliberated with Hasbro's 
lawyers so they can make a feature length My Little Pony fan film called 
"Journey of the Spark". Right now they're in the clear because Hasbro is 
turning a blind eye to it, and they're working hard to make it the way they 
want it without breaching any copyright.
comments.author: binkyboy448

as a result, though.

top_comment.author: Rek Uzumaki (うずまき)

comments.text:
i'm glad your headphone's are fine! now let's work on your perception.. 
what you call "yodeling" i call cringe worthy, because at the pitch she was 
using there was no need for her to alternate, so either it was bad timing 
or voice cracking. but between you and me, i'm pretty sure she didn't do 
that on purpose.. don't get me wrong i love the rest of the song, but that 
was an obvious crack
comments.author: Rek Uzumaki (うずまき)

comments.text:
It's not a voice crack it's a vocal technique called yodeling where the 
singer alternates between chest voice and head voice/falsetto, it is 
controlled and intentional and part of her signature style as showcased 
more clearly if you Google her song - Birds of a Feather Erutan. This cover 
took 1 month to make and she is a perfectionist who has been studying music 
her entire life and is more than capable of editing out anything she didn't 
want in the final product and has addressed this point herself personally 
before as her yodels/turns/ornaments have confused people before, so as a 
fan of hers for 7 years I can say I'm very sure she did do that on purpose, 
glad you like the song but please listen to Birds of a Feather as it is a 
masterclass on the technique!
comments.author: SuperWidgetMaster

lyrics to make it fit in better with the show itself. Anyways, the point of 
this song is that Princess Luna took the abandoned children in Equestria in 
order to give them a  new life without the fear and pain that they had 
experienced after the wake of Discord's reign. It's not really meant to be 
dark, but rather, it was meant to tell a story, short as it is, about how 
the children off the night came into being.

top_comment.text:
I just realized something that I bet most people don't! Luna may seem to be 
doing a wonderful, good thing, and her intentions were pure I'm sure, but 
think about it for a minute. Most of those filly's probably had actual 
blood-related parents and families, and Luna is not only stealing them from 
those families, but since they seem so willing to go with her and consider 
her their mother, she must also be putting a spell on them or something so 
they forget their old families! O_O﻿
top_comment.author: Daniel Zimmerman

comments.text:
Well, maybe most of them were like that. I agree with you on that, but 
there are definitely a few who were living with other families. If not 
blood-related families then at least pony's who they had grown to love and 
recognize as family.
comments.author: Daniel Zimmerman

comments.text:
I'm not so sure...

It seems implied that the majority of those who were taken were destitute 
in a variety of ways--either in orphanages or outright homeless.  Whatever 
birth parents they had, they clearly were not caring for those who were 
taken.

As for the bewitching...you might be on to something.  The song is all 
about promises of being taken away to an entirely new world.  Considering 
they were all being lifted up, both literally and figuratively, it was a 
pretty powerful bit of enchantment.

The physics of their world is very much different then both our world and 
the first generation's.The pony in the robe was one of the orphans that 
princess luna(the black/blue one singing) took with her. You can see her as 
a little filly on the top bunk bed at 1:54. I think in their official comic 
series that it mentions a magic that Luna has to allow who ever she wants 
on the moon with her to be able to breath or something close.  She'd likely 
fly back down and get them food if they got hungry.
The black thing they defeated is called discord and hes like an evil 
chimera since his body is a mishmash of random animal parts. He is a god of 
chaos and disrupted harmony for everyone.  The only way to stop him was 
turning him to stone and they were only able to do that by unlock a 
mysterious source of magic.

top_comment.text:
Oh god this is perfect... So let's back up and I'll share my idea of why 
this is so great.
Fall of the Crystal empire by silly filly studios. Luna defeats Sombra, and 
banished his whole empire! But unbeknownst to Celestia, she was infected by 
the nightmare force... She did her best to fight it... To conceal it... 
Years passed and eventually Discord's reign had nearly conquered all of 
Equestria. The sisters defeated him and rebuilt the kingdom... And Luna 
considered creating her own kingdom, whether it was her idea of the 
nightmare force that does not matter. Celestia was starting to see the 
darkness in her sister that had been growing ever since that fight with 
Sombra. She feared what might become of Luna, and she feared Luna's kingdom 
becoming like the Crystal Empire. This is why she refused... But the 
darkness only grew... And Luna, innocent in her own mind, listened to the 
whisper of the nightmare force... And began to build behind her sisters 
back... You can even hear her slight corruption as she sings about the 
perception of life "murdering beauty and passion"... But she's not 
Nightmare Moon yet... I'm going I go check out Daylight's End over at Silly 
Filly Studios' channel... I may add more there﻿

top_comment.text:
I can't help but think that this takes place AFTER the series, rather than 
before. Perhaps in a universe wherein Discord betrayed the elements and 
took over once more.
The city of Canterlot has already been established at this point, and the 
statue at the beginning looks uncannily like Twilight Sparkle - perhaps a 
casualty of the war? I don't see this as a start-of-darkness for Luna/NMM 
in this case (she's appreciated by her 'children', and she's not exactly 
malevolent - controlling, maybe, but even then not that much), and you can 
see a pony that resembles (though clearly isn't) Sweetie Belle - a 
descendant, perhaps? Maybe an ancestor, if it takes place prior to the 
series, but still.
God damn it, now I have to either read or write a fanfic based on this. 
Unless there's already one? I can't imagine this song not having a fanfic 
already.﻿

comments.text:
Changelings attack. War erupts against Changeling Empire. Ponies die. 
Twilight sacrifices life to stop Queen Chrysalis. Princess Celestia becomes 
a nervous wreck after the death of her student. Makes all the wrong choices 
to protect Equestria e.g Massive farms to produce food, secret police, 
making ponies work at factories and farms, etc. Massive amount of Orphans 
due to war. Luna asks for a creation of a country where the ponies work at 
night instead of in the morning so that demands can be met and so that 
ponies can be freed of the horrible working conditions. Celestia does not 
listen because she fears a possible revolution or uprising. Luna goes ahead 
and does it anyways and starts the Luna Republic in secret. Celestia finds 
out. War erupts once again. Celestia dies and Equestria is taken over by 
Luna.

The end.

comments.author: ruben rod

comments.text:
This short animation tells the tale of what would have been the origin of 
Nightmare Night, and the catalyst element that forced Celestia to banish 
Luna. 

After defeating Discord, Canterlot was witnessing a very slow recovery. 
Misery could still be found everywhere around, specially for the ponies 
that had less means. 

Luna thought that expanding the kingdom and founding a new pony colony 
elsewhere would put a solution to the problem, favoring the ponies that 
struggled the most. 

Celestia declined the proposal of her sister to scatter Equestria. For 
after such a great lack of harmony she thought it could shatter the kingdom 
forever. 

Being denied and in the shadow of her own sister, Luna decided to carry on 
with her plan, and ask for forgiveness rather than permission.

top_comment.author: Akoran Brighteye

comments.text:
The road to hell is paved with good intentions, as it were.
I think this story does good in keeping the issue of right and wrong 
ambiguous, though. Celestia has valid reasons not to allow Luna the 
creation of the colony, and Luna definitely went the moral low road by 
essentially drugging the entirety of Canterlot Castle and going against her 
sister's wishes.
Not to mention that while this version plays the song up as saving the 
foals from a worse fate, the original was unappologetically about 
kidnapping children for nefarious purposes.
comments.author: Smilley MLK

comments.text:
+Smilley MLK 
a) I realize that she means no ill intent, though that mainly means she 
does not realize why her actions are wrong and doesn't change them.
b) The main problem I find is exactly the fact that she is basically, 
intentionally or not, tricking them into coming with her as they cannot 
fully grasps their decision.
c) Well, most of them had shelters already (except few of them that were 
out on the street) and while Luna tries to nurture them, the fact that she 
later on becomes nightmare moon says to me at least is that she would not 
be stable enough to take care of them all, and again, you do not have to 
have ill intentions to do something wrong.

Really, the main problem I have with it all is how they try to portray Luna 
completely in the right and Celestia in the wrong even though Luna 
basically ended up kidnapping bunch of orphans, and according to that pony 
in the beginning wherever she brought them to they are isolated there from 
the rest of the world. It just really rubs me off the wrong way how it is 
portrayed, especially since it seems to be using this common stupid 
fancanon that celestia is basically a tyrant (despite nothing in the show 
says that, and a lot of it says the opposite) and Luna as this some kind of 
a genius that was more forward thinking (despite the fact that of the two 
she holds more traits of the old world, such as the royal canterlot voice). 
It doesn't help that half the people in this comment section basically are 
putting in comments that could be summed up as "Luna can not do any wrong", 
which is really infuriating seeing as she was the first VILLAIN in the show.
comments.author: 100aegir

comments.text:
+100aegir I realize that in the real world, this issue would be much more 
complex and morally ambiguous, and it does mark Luna's first act of 
defiance leading to her transformation to Nightmare Moon, but there are a 
few things to consider:
a) she means no malicious intent,
b) the children chose to follow her of  their own volition - though I 
realize they may not have grasped the extent of their decision, and
b) she is providing them with shelter, nurture and a sense of family.
In a sense, it was like building her own orphanage, to take in the shunned 
and downtrodden.
If taken from a darker angle - and that might have been the Nightmare Moon 
influence -, dhe could also have started building a cult of fanatics. It 
just depends on how much you want to read into it and how dark you want the 
story to be.
comments.author: Smilley MLK

comments.text:
+Smilley MLK So, by that statement it is perfectly okay to kidnap someone 
as long as they are orphans or castaways? I know you probably did not think 
through your statement out enough but you have to face it, what Luna did 
was pretty morally questionable.

top_comment.text:
One can easily tell that this video was done by amateurs. For instance, 
there's a glitch in the tail at 2:38, and the animation is generally choppy 
after the 3:00 mark. The singer's voice cracks at 2:16, but this is owed to 
the poor production of the video; the flaw is not present in Erutan's 
recording.

Why this has 67,987 likes, I do not know. Perhaps it's because bronies are 
accustomed to being fed shit and applauding mediocrity. Just look at the 
show they watch! A disgrace is such work, and all who enjoy it should be 
thoroughly ashamed of themselves. ﻿

comments.text:
First time I ever heard it was in the movie Hocus Pocus, sung by Sarah 
Jessica Parker. As for it being credited to Poe, that is almost entirely 
spurious, in a sense. It doesn't fit his style, his metaphor useage, or any 
of his known metres. It is also nowhere to be found in his works. Yet, with 
a bit of digging(not by me), it seems the original is credited to him, but 
over time the lyrics and music style has changed. If you want an 
interesting read about it, try out this little gem: 
http://www.dmelhoff.com/who-wrote-come-little-children
comments.author: William Voight

comments.text:
Oh, c'mon, both of you! Luna has a dark color scheme because she is 
associated with the night, and her Nightmare Moon persona especially with 
the fearsome nature of darkness.
Never in the series is her coat color refered to as anything derogatory or 
demeaning.
In fact, ponies come in all colors of the rainbow, and neither is 
represented as inherently better or worse than another.

If anyone, the zebra Zecora is associated with the concept of "foreigner", 
and the episode focusing on her is about not judging a book by its cover.

So please, again, both of you, don't call on the racist card where it isn't 
appropriate.

comments.text:
Actually, you can blame the Entertainment Media for screwing everything 
over, just like what they did with the Furry fandom and just about every 
single group in the entire planet. They go around and try to make a story, 
so they intentionally pick some of the worst, most outrageous people in the 
entire fandom to interview and then try to pass it off as the "normal" 
group. The Entertainment Media horribly screwed over the Furry fandom back 
during the 1980's and have been try to continue on it since then, but  the 
 Furry fandom has gotten a little wiser. They've got the right people 
behind them, like Kage, or, as most furries call him, "Uncle Kage." He's 
the main overseer of the major Furry conventions like Anthrocon and he 
essentially bars certain media outlets from entering and only lets in local 
news stations because they tend to be far  less bias and will report what 
the solely find. Any entertainment media groups are quickly kicked out in 
order to prevent them from screwing around and demonizing them any further. 

With the Brony Fandom, it's a similar thing. The Entertainment media sank 
their teeth into us and fed on us for money. They found the absolute worst 
parts they could find and them exploited them in order to make money off of 
us, while destroying our public image from the get-go. So, we're in the 
same boat and, in order to improve ourselves, we need to start improving 
our  public image by, for example, creating our own charities and setting 
an overall better example for the entire fandom.

captions.text: I still remember it like it was yesterday
Though it was countless moons ago
Not much of our once beautiful home was left

And the two brave ones that stood up for us
all
Proposed to form a new colony
Were all of us would grow strong and happy
But the elder one, forbade it...

For she felt that would divide and shatter
the weakened kingdom
Nopony knows that we are still here
Here in my garden of shadows
Through all the pain and the sorrows
Too weary of life and deceptions
Into the calm and the quiet
Here in my garden of shadows
